scenes.background: You are on annual leave, enjoying some well-deserved time off to recharge. However, during your time away, a colleague messages you privately, saying thereâ€™s an urgent task that needs immediate attention. The request creates a dilemma as you try to balance respecting your time off while feeling the pressure to help with the urgent task. You chose to take a quick look and help out. After some time, [Monica] and [Bob] approach you in the cafeteria. [Monica] looks slightly concerned while [Bob] seems indifferent. [Monica] says, 'Hey [Alex], I heard you helped out with the urgent task during your leave. That's really commendable, but don't you think it's setting a precedent for others to bother you on your days off?' You responded assertively, stating that maybe the team needs to be more self-reliant. Now, [Monica] frowns slightly and [Bob] raises an eyebrow. [Bob] remarks, 'Well, if everyone just starts saying no to extra work, won't that leave us in a bind during real emergencies?' You agreed with [Bob], saying perhaps you should have thought about the long-term implications. [Monica] now looks at you with a concerned expression and asks, 'So, what do you think we should do next time if there's another urgent task during someone's leave?' You proposed setting up a rotation system to handle emergencies without overburdening anyone.
scenes.description: [Bob], still looking skeptical, chimes in, 'But what if the rotation system fails? What would be our fallback plan?'

options.text: If the rotation system fails, we can always rely on our team spirit to get things done.
options.analysis: You offer a general reassurance, showing a balanced but somewhat ambiguous approach, with moderate scores across all dimensions.

options.text: You're right, Bob. Maybe we should consider having a dedicated emergency response team.
